keyMoments.title: Confronts Jinbe About Arlong
keyMoments.description: Nami directly asks Jinbe if he was responsible for sending Arlong to the East Blue, confronting the source of her eight years of suffering.
keyMoments.significance: This confrontation brings Nami's trauma to the forefront and connects her personal tragedy to the broader history of Fish-Man Island.
keyMoments.quote: Did you send Arlong to the East Blue?

keyMoments.title: Flashback to Arlong Park Trauma
keyMoments.description: Nami experiences painful flashbacks to her time under Arlong's control, including memories of Bell-mère and Nojiko.
keyMoments.significance: These flashbacks remind viewers of the emotional weight this conversation carries for Nami.
keyMoments.quote: No matter what, I will never forgive Arlong for what he did.

keyMoments.title: Realizes Connection Between Arlong Park and Sabaody Park
keyMoments.description: Nami notices that Arlong Park's design was identical to Sabaody Park, where fish-men were sold as slaves, revealing how Arlong's trauma influenced his cruelty.
keyMoments.significance: This observation adds depth to understanding the cycle of hatred and how victims can become victimizers.
keyMoments.quote: From two years ago on Sabaody, I noticed that Sabaody Park is identical to Arlong Park in design.

relationships.description: Nami confronts Jinbe about his connection to Arlong, seeking answers about her past suffering.

evolutionMoments.description: Nami directly asks Jinbe if he sent Arlong to the East Blue, creating tension.

reveals.information: Despite years passing, Nami still cannot forgive Arlong for what he did to her and her village
Nami noticed that Arlong Park's design was identical to Sabaody Park where fish-men were enslaved

keyMoments.title: Discovers Joy Boy's Poneglyph
keyMoments.description: Robin finds a Poneglyph in the Sea Forest and discovers it contains an apology letter from Joy Boy to the ancient Poseidon for breaking a promise about the ship Noah.
keyMoments.significance: This is the first mention of Joy Boy in the series, introducing a crucial figure in the world's ancient history.

keyMoments.title: Explores the Sea Forest
keyMoments.description: Robin continues her archaeological investigation of the Sea Forest where Fish-Man Island's Poneglyph is kept.
keyMoments.significance: Robin's dedication to uncovering history leads to important discoveries about the Void Century.

reveals.information: Joy Boy left an apology letter on a Poneglyph to the ancient mermaid princess Poseidon

keyMoments.title: Confronted by Nami About Arlong
keyMoments.description: Jinbe is directly confronted by Nami about whether he sent Arlong to the East Blue, forcing him to face his connection to Nami's suffering.
keyMoments.significance: This confrontation sets up Jinbe's flashback arc explaining his history with Arlong and the Sun Pirates.

keyMoments.title: Explains Fish-Men and Human Relations History
keyMoments.description: Jinbe begins explaining the 200-year history of discrimination between fish-men and humans.
keyMoments.significance: This exposition provides crucial context for understanding the Fish-Man Island arc's themes.
keyMoments.quote: The relationship between fish-men and humans has stayed the same, even over 200 years.

keyMoments.title: Introduces Fisher Tiger and Queen Otohime
keyMoments.description: Jinbe introduces the two legendary figures who tried to change Fish-Man Island's history: Fisher Tiger and Queen Otohime.
keyMoments.significance: This sets up the major flashback arc that will reveal Jinbe's past and his connection to Arlong.
keyMoments.quote: Two people rose to power to change history: the hero of slaves, Fisher Tiger, and the late queen, Otohime.

relationships.description: Jinbe must explain to Nami his connection to Arlong and take responsibility for the pain Arlong caused.

evolutionMoments.description: Nami confronts Jinbe about sending Arlong to the East Blue.

relationships.description: Jinbe was a member of Fisher Tiger's Sun Pirates and admired him greatly.

evolutionMoments.description: Jinbe introduces Fisher Tiger as the hero of slaves who changed history.

reveals.information: Jinbe has deep knowledge of Fish-Man Island's 200-year history of discrimination
Jinbe is connected to both Fisher Tiger and Arlong's history

name.japanese: フィッシャー・タイガー

keyMoments.title: Introduced as Hero of Slaves
keyMoments.description: Fisher Tiger is introduced by Jinbe as a legendary hero who freed fish-men slaves from the World Nobles and attempted to change Fish-Man Island's history.
keyMoments.significance: Fisher Tiger is a pivotal figure whose actions shaped modern Fish-Man Island and influenced characters like Jinbe and Arlong.

statusHistory.reason: Mentioned as deceased; full story to be revealed in flashback

relationships.description: Fisher Tiger was Jinbe's captain and inspiration in the Sun Pirates.

evolutionMoments.description: Jinbe introduces Fisher Tiger as a legendary figure he followed.

reveals.information: Fisher Tiger was known as the hero of slaves who freed fish-men from the World Nobles
Fisher Tiger was one of two people who rose to power to change Fish-Man Island's history

keyMoments.title: Citizens Forced to Step on Her Image
keyMoments.description: The New Fish-Man Pirates force citizens to step on a fumi-e of Queen Otohime's image, desecrating her memory and ideals.
keyMoments.significance: This demonstrates how the New Fish-Man Pirates have perverted Otohime's message of peace between fish-men and humans.

keyMoments.title: Introduced as Advocate for Peace
keyMoments.description: Queen Otohime is introduced by Jinbe as King Neptune's late wife who advocated for peaceful coexistence between fish-men and humans.
keyMoments.significance: Otohime is a pivotal figure whose ideals continue to influence Fish-Man Island even after her death.

statusHistory.reason: Mentioned as late queen; circumstances to be revealed in flashback

relationships.description: Queen Otohime was King Neptune's wife and queen of the Ryugu Kingdom.

evolutionMoments.description: Otohime is introduced as King Neptune's late wife.

relationships.description: Otohime and Fisher Tiger represented opposing philosophies for achieving fish-men's freedom and equality.

evolutionMoments.description: Introduced as the two leaders who attempted to change Fish-Man Island's history through different means.

reveals.information: Queen Otohime was King Neptune's wife and advocated for peace between fish-men and humans
Even after death, Queen Otohime's ideals are so revered that citizens feel remorse when forced to step on her image

keyMoments.title: Defends Nami During Confrontation
keyMoments.description: Sanji protectively warns Jinbe that what he says next will determine whether he forgives him, emphasizing how hard Nami suffered under Arlong.
keyMoments.significance: Demonstrates Sanji's protective nature toward Nami and his anger toward anyone who caused her pain.
keyMoments.quote: Nami had it hard with Arlong for eight long years. What you say next will decide if I forgive you or not.

keyMoments.title: Forces Citizens to Step on Otohime's Fumi-e
keyMoments.description: Hyouzou forces Fish-Man Island citizens to step on Queen Otohime's image as a loyalty test, threatening to kill or exile those who refuse.
keyMoments.significance: Demonstrates the New Fish-Man Pirates' extremism and their hatred for Otohime's ideals of peace.
keyMoments.quote: Either step on the fumi-e or get off the island. Otherwise, I'll cut you down.
